An efficient carbon material was prepared using hydrothermal carbonization of birch-wood chips in the water under elevated pressure, subsequent chemical activation, and doping with nitrogen. The obtained catalyst had a large specific surface area of 2431 m2 g−1 and a high nitrogen content of 4.60 at.%. Most of the nitrogen was in the pyridinic-N (57.61 at.%) form. The synthesized material exhibits excellent electro-catalytic activity for the oxygen reduction reaction with an onset potential of 0.9 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode, showing the 4e− electrons transfer path in 0.1 M KOH solution. Keywords Birch-wood chips Hydrothermal carbonization Nitrogen-doped carbon Oxygen reduction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Renewable energy generation remains insufficient to meet the ever-increasing energy demand. Research and development of technologies for fuel cells, supercapacitors, Li- and Na-batteries, as well as improvement of their characteristics, are widely studied worldwide. In numerous power conversion devices, such as low-temperature fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and electrolyzers, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays a significant role [1]. Despite numerous studies to improve performance, efficiency, and durability, large-scale commercialization of fuel cells remains problematic [2,3]. One of the main problems is the high price of widely used platinum-based catalysts [4] and their limited availability, making the cost of platinum-containing electrodes more than 70% of the cost of the fuel cell itself. Therefore, it is essential to reduce the cost of fuel cells by replacing platinum with other materials, particularly porous carbon materials, while maintaining catalytic efficiency. Numerous studies prove that highly porous carbon materials with a microporous structure can be obtained by alkaline thermochemical activation using carbonized biomass as a precursor [5]. Carbonization of biomass residues followed by activation has great potential to become an environmentally friendly process for the production of various carbon materials for environmental, catalytic, electronic, and agricultural applications [6–11]. A new type of carbonization is hydrothermal carbonization (HTC) - an environmentally friendly technology for producing a solid carbon material called hydrochar. The process takes place in water at elevated temperature and pressure, with the aim of breaking CC and CO bonds of biomass using two mechanisms: an ionic or polar reaction mechanism typical of liquid phase chemistry at low temperature and a free radical reaction mechanism typical of gas phase reactions at high temperature [12]. These reactions include but are not limited to hydrolysis, isomerization, dehydration, decarboxylation, decarbonylation, etc. In the past few years, HTC has attracted significant attention due to its ability to convert biomass wastes, including wet ones, into carbon materials with useful characteristics, facilitating efficient use for adsorption [7,8], catalysis [10,11], and activated carbon synthesis [13–15]. Published studies have reported on the hydrothermal carbonization of materials, including cellulose [13,14], switchgrass and corn stover [15], wood [16], microalgae [12], swine manure [17], and sugars such as xylose [18], glucose [19], sucrose and starch [13]. Depending on the activation method, the specific surface area of the obtained carbon materials may exceed the theoretical values in accordance with the standard Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory [20]. Published works indicate that alkalis KOH and NaOH can be used for alkaline chemical activation, but the main amount of research is devoted to the more expensive KOH, and only in rare cases the authors use NaOH. In contrast to carbonizates obtained by biomass pyrolysis, the aromatic structure of hydrochar contains high concentrations of oxygen functional groups (OFG), which promotes vigorous interaction with alkali during the activation stage [16,21–23]. However, the presence of oxygen in the activated carbon can be regarded as a negative property of the material, as it inhibits the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the fuel cell electrode [9]. One possibility for optimizing this reaction is the use of doping with transition metals and/or heteroatoms [10,17,24]. Currently, platinum-based materials are generally used to accelerate the ORR process, which is one of the factors compromising the feasibility and widespread use of otherwise promising fuel cell applications. For example, the addition of nitrogen moieties with higher electronegativity will generate a positive charge density on carbon and O2 atoms and chemisorption will change, which in turn also effectively weakens the OO bond and thereby contribute to ORR [24–26]. In general, there are a number of changes in the material, which can facilitate ORR due to N addition, such as disturbance in electroneutrality, change in spin density, redistribution of charge, as well as binding states. The state of nitrogen in the carbon matrix is important since the catalytic activity has the following order - pyridinic, pyrrolic, graphitic-N, oxidized-N, carbon [27]. In this study, activated carbon samples for ORR were prepared via hydrothermal carbonization using wood chips in the water under elevated pressure, activated with alkali, and doped with nitrogen. The efficiency of the synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon material (N-HTC) for ORR was evaluated using the rotating disk electrode (RDE) and ring-disk electrode (RRDE) methods and compared with undoped activated carbon (HTC) and commercial Pt/C catalyst. 2 Experimental Synthesis of carbon material. The activated carbon sample was synthesized using three stages. Firstly, 300 g of dry birch-wood chips and 4 L of distilled water were hydrothermally carbonized under elevated pressure at 250 °C for 4 h in Parr 4554 reactor (volume 7.5 L) stainless steel autoclave. Then, the obtained sample was ground for 1 h at 300 rpm (Fritsch Pulverizette planetary mill) and activated with NaOH (activator ratio carbon to NaOH = 1:3) at 800 °C in an inert argon (Ar) atmosphere. After cooling, the samples were treated for 2 h in a 10% HCl solution, washed with demineralized water to pH 5–6, and dried in the oven at 105 ± 2 °C for 12 h. To introduce nitrogen into the material structure, dicyandiamide (DCDA) in dimethylformamide (DMF) solution was used, and then the solvent was evaporated using a rotary evaporator. The resulting solid material was doped at 800 °C in an inert Ar atmosphere. Characterization of carbon materials. Quantachrome Nova 4200e instrument (Quantachrome Instruments, FL, USA) was used for the determination of the specific surface area (SSA) (m2 g−1), micropore and total pore volume (m3 g−1), and pore size distribution (nm) of the samples by recording and analysis of N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K [20]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of samples was accomplished using Tecnai G2 F20 X-TWIN microscope (FEI, Eindhoven, Netherlands) [28]. The chemical composition of the samples was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) utilizing Kratos AXIS Supra+ spectrometer (Kratos Analytical, UK, Manchester) as described in Ref. [29]. Raman spectra were recorded using inVia Raman spectrometer (Renishaw, UK) equipped with a thermoelectrically cooled (−70 °C) CCD camera and microscope, as given in Ref. [5]. Additionally, the laser power at the sample was restricted to 0.4 mW to avoid damaging the sample. Electrochemical measurements. Determination of catalyst activity for ORR was carried out using a potentiostat/galvanostat PGSTAT100 with a rotating disk electrode (RDE) (Metrohm Autolab B. V., Utrecht, The Netherlands). A standard electrochemical cell was used, whereas a glassy carbon (GC) with a geometric area of 0.19625 cm2 was used as a working electrode. The Pt sheet and Ag/AgCl in 3 M KCl were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurements were performed using a bipotentiostat/galvanostat PGSTAT302N/BA with the RRDE electrode tip, which consists of a 5 mm disc of GC with a concentric platinum ring at a distance of 375 μm (Metrohm Autolab B. V., Utrecht, The Netherlands). This configuration resulted in a theoretical collection efficiency of 24.9%. The platinum ring geometric area was 0.072 cm2. The catalyst ink (2 mg mL−1) was prepared as follows: 2 mg of the synthesized HTC or N-HTC catalysts was dispersed ultrasonically for 2 h in a mixture of 300 μL isopropanol, 700 μL deionized water, and 8 μL 5 wt% Nafion. Then, 40 μL of the prepared suspension mixture was pipetted onto the GC of RDE or RRDE and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 4 h. The catalyst loading was 0.4044 μg cm−2. Linear-sweep voltammograms (LSVs) were recorded in a 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with O2 at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 and varied rotation rates (ω) from 400 to 2400 rpm. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded in the 0.1 M KOH solutions, which were saturated with Ar or O2. The scan rate was 10 mV s−1. The electrode potential values were quoted versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). Then, the measured current densities were normalized to the geometric area of catalysts. For comparison, a commercial Pt/C catalyst (Tanaka, 46.4 wt% Pt) with a catalyst loading of 81.6 μg cm−2 was used. The accelerated durability test for N-HTC and Pt/C was conducted by cycling the catalyst 1000 times between 1.0 and 0.6 V vs. RHE at 800 rpm at a scan rate of 200 mV s−1. After 1000 cycles, an LSV was recorded from 1.0 to 0.25 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. For the RRDE measurements, the ring electrode potential was set to 1.5 V vs. RHE, and the current response was recorded at 10 mV s−1. 3 Results and discussion Hydrothermally treated wood chips were used as a precursor for producing alkali-activated (NaOH) carbon materials (HTC) and nitrogen-doped (N-HTC) for testing as oxygen reduction catalysts. The specific surface area (BET) (Table 1 ) and pore size distribution (Fig. 1a, b) were assessed using N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77 K. Both samples belong to micro-mesoporous carbon materials with highly developed porous structures and specific porous surface areas of more than 2400 m2 g−1 each. The material porous structure is formed during activation and changes negligibly after doping with nitrogen. Fig. 1b shows that since the pore walls break and the pore size increases during the reheating in the doping process, the number of micropores slightly decreases. The input of mesopores into the total porous volume for the activated and doped carbonaceous material is 57%, which is important to note since mesopores facilitate mass transfer and, therefore, diminish the influence of diffusion issues [30]. The elemental analysis results revealed that doping is successful since the majority of oxygen-containing groups was replaced by nitrogen. Because of doping, the nitrogen content in the N-HTC carbon material structure has increased to 5.1%, while the oxygen content decreased by 3.7%. Fig. 2 presents the TEM (a) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (b) images of the N-HTC. Rumpled, multi-layered graphene sheet-like morphology is seen (Fig. 2a, b). The elemental composition and element-binding configurations at the surface of the N-HTC were investigated via XPS. Fig. 3a presents a representative XPS survey spectrum for N-HTC that demonstrated the existence of C, N, and O. The deconvoluted XPS spectra of C 1 s, N 1 s, and O 1 s for N-HTC are given in Fig. 3b-d. The high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectrum was split into five peaks: 284.2 (Csp2, 12.14 at.%), 284.8 (Csp3, 54.38 at.%), 285.3 (N-sp2-C, 17.12 at.%), 286.4 (N-sp3-C, 14.77 at.%), and 287.0 (CO, 3.59 at.%) eV [31–33]. Additionally, the N 1 s peak was fitted and the three-component peaks were identified as pyridinic-N (398.5 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.1 eV), and quaternary nitrogen, an N atom with a formal charge of +1, e.g. (protonated) pyridinic-N (401.1 eV). The overall nitrogen content on the N-HTC surface was 4.60%. However, most nitrogen was in the pyridinic form (57.61%), which is widely recognized as the ORR-active species [34]. Resonance Raman spectroscopy was used to get insights into the studied carbon material structure. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra for carbon material before (HTC) and post‑nitrogen doping (N-HTC). Both samples exhibit two strong bands visible at 1346–1348 cm−1 and 1595–1606 cm−1 belonging to prominent D and G modes of graphite structure, respectively [35–39] (Fig. 4). The important structural parameter, in-plane crystalline size of sp2-hybridized carbon (L α) can be obtained by analysis full width at half maximum of G band, FWHM(G) [39–43]: (1) L a = l c 2 ln C FWHM G − FWHM G 0 where photon coherence length l c = 32 nm, C = 95 cm−1, and FWHM(G) and FWHM(G0) are the widths of the G band of the sample under investigation and pristine graphene (15 cm−1), respectively. Therefore, the experimental Raman spectra in the frequency region from 1000 to 1800 cm−1 were fitted by 4 Gaussian or Gaussian-Lorentzian form components (Fig. 4). In the fitting procedure, two Gaussian from components D* and D″ were introduced at 1275 and 1520 cm−1, respectively [40,44]. The presence of D″ indicates amorphization of carbon material [39,45]. The estimated L α values were found to be 5.5 and 6.1 nm for HCT and N-HCT samples, respectively. Thus, N-HTC sample shows a slightly higher degree of crystallinity. In addition, the intensity ratio I(D″)/I(G) can be used to probe the amorphization of carbon material. A higher ratio was found in the case of the HCT sample (0.58) compared with N-HTC one (0.54). Thus, both parameters extracted from the Raman spectra indicate higher disordering in the case of the HTC sample. It should be noted that the overtone of the D band (2D-mode) is not visible in the vicinity of 2700 cm−1. This indicates that the sp2-hybridized carbon network of the studied samples is highly disordered, which is consistent with established relatively low L α values and high I(D″)/I(G) ratios. Fig. 5a presents the CVs of N-HTC recorded in Ar-deaerated and O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solutions. No distinct redox peak is seen in a 0.1 M KOH solution deaerated with Ar. In contrast, an apparent reduction peak in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution is observed at approximately 0.8 V, indicating the catalytic activity of this catalyst toward ORR. Additionally, the ORR performance was evaluated by recording LSVs on the RDE in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at varied rotation speeds in the range from 400 to 2400 rpm at 10 mV s−1 (Fig. 5b). With the increased rotation rate, the limiting current density grows accordingly. A comparison of ORR LSVs recorded for the N-HTC, HTC, and commercial Pt/C catalysts in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at 1600 rpm is presented in Fig. 5c. The onset potential (marked as the potential at an ORR current density of −0.1 mA cm−2) is equal to approximately 0.9 V for N-HTC and is already adjacent to that of Pt/C catalyst (0.95 V) (Fig. 5c) [46]. The half-wave potential (E 1/2) for N-HTC was equal to approximately 0.82 V, which is very close to the E 1/2 value for the commercial Pt/C catalyst, i.e., 0.823 V (Fig. 5c). Notably, the onset and E 1/2 potentials for the undoped HTC material is approximately 0.87 V and 0.76 V, respectively, whose are lower compared with N-HTC. Doping of activated carbon material with nitrogen results in the shift of the onset and E 1/2 potentials to more positive values, indicating a higher activity of N-HTC sample. Moreover, for the evaluation of ORR activity and quality of the synthesized N-HTC material, the Tafel analysis was used. The empirical Tafel equation (Eq. (2)) is based on a linear region between the logarithms of measured current density and the applied potential: (2) η = a + blogj where η (V) is the applied overpotential, a (V) is the curve intercept, b (V dec−1) is the Tafel plot, and j (A cm−2) is the resulting current density. Tafel slope (Fig. 5c, the inset) indicates that the current density changes as a function of rising overpotential. A smaller Tafel slope means the low overpotential needs to reach a high current density. Fig. 5 c, the inset presents the mass-transfer corrected Tafel plots using the Koutecky-Levich equation, where the kinetic current density for ORR (j k) could be calculated according to the Eq. (3): (3) j k = j L j j L − j where j L is the O2-diffusion-limited current density at 0.4 V vs. RHE measured at 1600 rpm, and j is the Faradaic current density. The low Tafel slope values of −49.9 and − 64 mV dec−1 were obtained for N-HTC and Pt/C catalysts, indicating a high activity for ORR (Fig. 5c, the inset). For HTC sample, a higher Tafel slope value of −75.6 mV was obtained, showing that a higher overpotential is needed to achieve a high current density. The number of electrons transferred per O2 molecule (n) was calculated using the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) Eqs. (4)–(6) [47]: (4) 1 j = 1 j k + 1 j d = 1 B ω 1 / 2 + 1 j k (5) B = 0.62 nF C 0 D 0 2 / 3 ν − 1 / 6 (6) j k = nF kC 0 where j, j k, and j d are the experimentally measured current density, kinetic and diffusion-limiting current densities, respectively; k is the electrochemical rate constant for O2 reduction, F is the Faraday constant (96,485C mol−1), C0 is the concentration of oxygen in bulk (1.2 × 10−6 mol cm−3), D0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 (1.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1), ν is the kinematic viscosity of the solution (0.01 cm2 s−1), and ω (rad s−1) is the rotation rate of the electrode [48]. Fig. 5d presents the Koutecky–Levich (K-L) plots of the N-HTC catalyst in the range of potentials from 0.30 up to 0.65. All the K–L plots show good linearity, allowing the determination of electron numbers transferred during the ORR process. Furthermore, a linear relationship between j −1 and ω –1/2 indicates the first-order dependence of the ORR kinetics at varied potentials (0.30–0.65 V). Fig. 5 d, the inset reveals the electron number n transferred at various potentials at the N-HTC catalyst. As shown, a value of n close to 4 on all studied potentials (Fig. 5 d, the inset) was obtained on N-HTC material, indicating the direct 4e− reduction pathway from O2 to H2O predominantly. A high activity of N-HTC may be attributed to the highly developed porous structure and specific porous surface area of 2431 m2 g−1, and the advisable proportion of mesopores volume to total volume of 57%, allowing facilitate mass transfer and, therefore, diminish the influence of diffusion issues [30]. Furthermore, N-HTC contains 4.60% of the nitrogen, most of which is in the pyridinic form (57.61%), thus creating active sites for ORR, as reported in the literature [34]. However, the exact catalytic role of each nitrogen form in carbon-based catalysts for ORR is still controversial [48–50]. The accelerated durability test for N-HTC and Pt/C was conducted in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with O2 at 800 rpm by cycling the catalyst 1000 times between 1.0 and 0.6 V vs. RHE at 200 mV s−1. Then, the LSVs were recorded on the same catalysts at 10 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 e, f). No noticeable changes in the half-wave and onset potentials can be observed when comparing ORR activities of the N-HTC before and after 1000 potential cycles. In the case of Pt/C catalyst, an obvious negative shift of 24 and 15 mV is observed in the onset and half-wave potentials, respectively. The stability tests show that N-HTC sample has excellent stability as compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst. Further insight into the ORR mechanism can be obtained using the RRDE measurements, allowing the evaluation of HO2 − ions generated during O2 reduction [51]. Moreover, the HO2 − produced at the disk electrode is oxidized at the ring electrode, held at a constant potential, so that the ring current represents the peroxide quantity formed at the disk. Fig. 6 shows the LSVs of N-HTC recorded at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at a rotation rate of 1600 rpm (b) and a constant E ring of 1.5 V (a). Therefore, HO2 − yield was calculated using the data from Fig. 6 and Eq. (7): (7) % H O 2 − = 2 I R N I D + I R N ∙ 100 % Moreover, the number of electrons transferred in the reaction can be determined more accurately according to the following Eq. (8) [52]: (8) n = 4 I D I D + I R N where n is the number of electrons transferred, N is the collection efficiency, and IR and ID are the ring and disk currents, respectively. The results for determining a number of electrons transferred and % of H2O2 obtained using the N-HTC catalyst are summarized in Fig. 7 . The results revealed that the number of electrons transferred (n = approximately 4) stays almost constant within the potential range from 0.25 to 0.60 V (Fig. 7a). The obtained results correlate well with that of the Koutecky–Levich analysis. As shown in Fig. 7b, the amount of formed H2O2 (%) remains relatively very low (below approximately 0.32–0.375%), revealing that the major pathway is the direct conversion of O2 to H2O. Additionally, a minor two-electron reaction pathway existed with the formation of small amounts of H2O2. The RDE and RRDE results confirm the high ORR efficiency of the N-HTC catalyst and its application as a potential candidate as the cathode material in fuel cells. 4 Conclusions A method has been developed for obtaining an efficient and cheap electrocatalyst for ORR using hydrothermal carbonization of birch chips followed by activation with NaOH (3:1, 800 °C) and doping with nitrogen. Activated carbon material and nitrogen-doped carbon material had high specific porous surface areas of more than 2400 m2 g−1 and a micro-mesoporous structure with more than 50% of the mesopore volume. Because of doping, the nitrogen content in the carbon material was 4.60%, of which 57.61% was in the pyridinic form. The nitrogen-doped carbon material showed excellent electro-catalytic activity toward ORR with onset and half-wave potentials of approximately 0.9 and 0.82 V, respectively, indicative of a 4e electron transport pathway in an alkaline 0.1 M KOH solution. In addition, the N-HTC catalyst showed good durability when tested for 1000 cycles. This work demonstrates an efficient and sustainable approach to developing green energy-related material while considering biorefinery concepts. The synthesized excellent N-HTS material is a promising alternative to state-of-the-art precious metal-based catalysts for fuel cells, metal-air batteries, etc. CRediT authorship contribution statement Daina Upskuviene: Investigation, Visualization. coredata.dc:description: An efficient carbon material was prepared using hydrothermal carbonization of birch-wood chips in the water under elevated pressure, subsequent chemical activation, and doping with nitrogen. The obtained catalyst had a large specific surface area of 2431 m2 g−1 and a high nitrogen content of 4.60 at.%. Most of the nitrogen was in the pyridinic-N (57.61 at.%) form. The synthesized material exhibits excellent electro-catalytic activity for the oxygen reduction reaction with an onset potential of 0.9 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode, showing the 4e− electrons transfer path in 0.1 M KOH solution.
